channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: How Uber Got Lost
item.description: The once-swaggering company is losing more money and growing more slowly than ever. What happened?
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac

item.title: Google Tries to Corral Its Staff After Ugly Internal Debates
item.description: The tech company, telling its employees to “stop disrupting the workday,” issued new workplace rules designed to rein in its freewheeling culture.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Google is setting new rules to restrain freewheeling discussions among its employees during their work hours.

item.title: Facebook Bans Ads From The Epoch Times
item.description: The social network has struggled to implement a consistent political advertising policy as groups appear able to get around its transparency rules.
item.dc:creator: Davey Alba

item.title: The Week in Tech: Facebook’s First Step Toward Treating Our Data Better
item.description: The social network’s latest privacy feature at least lets us imagine how we could better control our data in the future.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Condliffe
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook, which introduced a data privacy tool this week.

item.title: Is It Time to Upend the Periodic Table?
item.description: The iconic chart of elements has served chemistry well for 150 years. But it’s not the only option out there, and scientists are pushing its limits.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Cadillac’s Last Stand? Storied Brand Aims (Again) for Revival
item.description: Once the epitome of luxury, the high-end General Motors line is attempting another makeover to catch up with rivals that have overtaken it.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Cadillac CT6 in Detroit. Although it is equipped with the Super Cruise driver-assistance system, the model’s sales have fallen 60 percent this year, and General Motors may halt production.

item.title: Lawsuit Over Computer Chips Invokes Trade War With China
item.description: Globalfoundries has accused T.S.M.C., a competitor in Taiwan, of infringing on 16 patents in a suit that could also affect companies like Apple and Google.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark
item.media:description: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company’s headquarters in Hsinchu, Taiwan. The company is a huge manufacturer of chips designed by other companies.

item.title: Qualcomm Wins Reprieve in F.T.C. Antitrust Case With Appeals Court Ruling
item.description: A federal appeals court ruled that the chip maker did not have to modify key business practices while the court reviews a lower-court ruling against the company.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark
item.media:description: A federal appeals court stayed a lower-court ruling that would force Qualcomm to alter business practices the Federal Trade argues are anticompetitive.

item.title: As Amazon Fires Spread, So Do the Misleading Photos
item.description: The fires are real. But the photographs that celebrities and politicians are sharing? Well, it depends.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi

item.title: Snapchat’s Disappearing Act Leaves Venice Beach Searching for Its Future
item.description: Snap changed social media — and Venice, Calif. — for good. What’s next?
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hernandez
item.media:credit: Adam Amengual for The New York Times
item.media:description: Street performers have had a big role in shaping Venice’s creative ethos.

item.title: YouTube Disables 210 Channels That Spread Disinformation About Hong Kong Protests
item.description: Days after Facebook and Twitter cracked down on China-backed accounts that were spreading such disinformation, YouTube did the same.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger

item.title: Soap, Detergent and Even Laxatives Could Turbocharge a Battery Alternative
item.description: Researchers are trying to develop options to lithium-ion and other batteries in a quest for quick bursts of power and extended energy storage.
item.dc:creator: XiaoZhi Lim

item.title: Alibaba Postpones Hong Kong Listing as Protests Roil Markets
item.description: The Chinese e-commerce giant delayed plans to sell potentially billions of dollars worth of shares in the market, which has fallen as tensions have worsened.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: The headquarters of Alibaba, in the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou. The e-commerce giant has a number of reasons to stick to its plan to list shares in Hong Kong.

item.title: Inside India’s Messy Electric Vehicle Revolution
item.description: A million electric rickshaws sprang up out of nowhere and are now being used by 60 million people a day. The government and vehicle makers are struggling to catch up.
item.dc:creator: Saumya Khandelwal, Vindu Goel and Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Electric rickshaw drivers must fight for space with buses and other vehicles outside Delhi metro stations.

item.title: How a Conservative News Site Thrived on Facebook and Google
item.description: The Western Journal has had one of the biggest online audiences. But it now finds itself clashing with Silicon Valley tech giants. Here are highlights from a Times investigation.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:credit: Stuart Isett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Floyd G. Brown, right, a longtime conservative political activist, in 2008.

item.title: Instagram’s Chain-Letter Uprising
item.description: Hordes of confused Instagrammers are trying to declare sovereignty from Instagram. Do they accidentally have a point?
item.dc:creator: John Herrman
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: YouTuber’s Surprise Discovery Gives Parents Last Look at Son They Lost
item.description: Rich Abernathy was filming a dive for YouTube when he found an old GoPro partly buried in the muck. “It’s like he’s right here,” said Robin McCrear of seeing the video footage of her son, Richard Lee Ragland III, who died in 2017.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin

item.title: How to Turn an iPhone Into a Work-Only Tool
item.description: To prevent distractions, Conor Dougherty, an economics writer, dumped social media and anything fun — even his browser — from his smartphone.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty
item.media:description: Connor Dougherty maintains his mobile phone as a work tool, packing it with news, maps and other service apps, but no social media. “I find this keeps me mostly sane and mostly productive,” he said.

item.title: M.I.T. Media Lab in Crisis After 2 Scholars Vow to Leave Over Epstein Ties
item.description: After last week’s apology from the research center’s director, Joichi Ito, Ethan Zuckerman and J. Nathan Matias said they were protesting the institute’s connection to the financier.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu, Marc Tracy and Emily Flitter
item.media:description: Ethan Zuckerman, an associate professor at the M.I.T. Media Lab, said he would leave the research institute over its ties to Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: How Many Triangles Are There? Here’s How to Solve the Puzzle
item.description: Counting will get you nowhere. Try a little combinatorics instead.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: Hi, Alexa. How Do I Stop You From Listening In On Me?
item.description: Humans help train artificial intelligence, so someone may be listening to what you tell Siri, Google Assistant or Alexa. Here’s what to do if you have a problem with that.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen

item.title: Scorsese’s New Mob Epic, ‘The Irishman,’ Has Netflix and Theaters at Odds
item.description: Will the movie, which stars Robert De Niro, come to a theater near you? After months of talks, there is still no resolution.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Martin Scorsese’s next movie, “The Irishman,” a decade-spanning epic starring Robert De Niro, is coming soon from Netflix.

item.title: Hollywood’s Premier Fashion Camp, for Ages 6 and Up
item.description: Kids spend a week learning to sew and self-brand, and then, of course, they walk the runway.
item.dc:creator: Arit John
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A week of fashion camp ends with an elaborate runway show, put on for parents and friends.

item.title: The Collective Memory of American Shoppers
item.description: On Facebook and Reddit, retail-focused groups remember the heyday of malls and share stories of shuttered department stores.
item.dc:creator: Kelsey Lawrence
item.media:credit: H. Armstrong Roberts/Retrofile, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Remember what malls were like in the 1960s? Some folks in retail-focused Facebook groups sure do.

item.title: Inside America’s Dysfunctional Trillion-Dollar Fighter-Jet Program
item.description: The F-35 was once the Pentagon’s high-profile problem child. Has it finally moved past its reputation of being an overhyped and underperforming warplane?
item.dc:creator: Valerie Insinna
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Anne Rearick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Airmen performing pre- and postflight inspections on the F-35A Lightning IIs at Mountain Home Air Force Base in Idaho.

item.title: FogCam Is Signing Off in San Francisco
item.description: Long before streaming video, it captured images of campus life every 20 seconds. The quirky project, believed to be the longest-running public webcam, will shut down at the end of August.
item.dc:creator: Laura M. Holson
item.media:description: Two grad students at San Francisco State created the FogCam in the early days of the web and kept it going for 25 years.

item.title: ‘I’m Sick of Seeing My Face,’ Says the Internet’s Kombucha Connoisseur
item.description: A woman’s taste test captured the fancy of the internet. Her rapid evolution of expressions may be why.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

item.title: How Should Big Tech Be Reined In? Here Are 4 Prominent Ideas
item.description: Some critics of the industry want to see the businesses broken up. Others would like to strengthen regulation of Silicon Valley. And there are shades of gray.
item.dc:creator: Steve Lohr
item.media:credit: Valerie Chiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tim Wu, a Columbia Law School professor, believes Facebook should have to shed some of the companies it has bought. “The remedy is straightforward,” he said.

item.title: Welcome to McDonald’s. Would You Like a Podcast With Those Fries?
item.description: With podcasts rising in popularity, it’s no surprise that companies are producing their own. What’s more surprising is that people are actually listening to them.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany

item.title: Facebook’s New Tool Lets You See Which Apps and Websites Tracked You
item.description: The tool is a response to criticism that Facebook has faced over how it safeguards its users’ privacy.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, has pledged to give users more control over their personal information.

item.title: China’s Soft-Power Failure: Condemning Hong Kong’s Protests
item.description: Beijing wants greater sway over global public opinion. Instead, its propaganda outlets make Chinese leaders look like bullies.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered at Victoria Park in Hong Kong over the weekend.
